DOC.HEAD: Winter Cold Reached Many Of The Gulf Of Mexico States
DOC.TEXT: Cold weather extended deep into the South and the Southwest on Wednesday, with record lows in the nation's midsection, and heavy snow fell around Lake Erie. Overnight temperatures reached 32 degrees or lower as far as much of North Carolina, south carolina, northern Georgia, northern Alabama, northern Mississippi, much of Louisiana, northern two-thirds of Texas, New Mexico, northeastern two-thirds of Arizona, east-central and north-central California, eastern two-thirds of Oregon, and the eastern half of Washington state. Below zero temperatures extended from across the upper half of the Plains, western Ohio, northern Maine, and the northeastern half of Montana. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 34 below zero at International Falls and Warroad, Minn. Unofficially, Embarrass, in northeastfern Minnesota, reached 37 degrees below zero. Wednesday's record lows were 2 at Calico Rock, Ark.; 9 at Hot Springs, Ark.; 4 at Paducah, Ky.; 12 below zero at Peoria, Ill.; 14 below at Springfield, Ill.; and 11 below at Waukesha, Wis. More than 100 low temperature records for the date have been broken or tied during the past week. At noon, wind chill effects over South Dakota ranged from 20 below zero in the south to 50 below zero in the north. Wind chills reached 45 below zero in Upper Michigan. Snow fell at midday over northeastern New York state, from northwestern through east-central Pennsylvania, across northeastern Ohio, over western Lower Michigan, from northwestern Illinois across southwestern Wisconsin, Iowa, southern Minnesota, South Dakota, Nebraska, northwestern Wyoming and Montana. In the snow belt of western New York state, where the moisture of Lake Erie contributes to ``lake effect'' snow, a highway was closed by 4-foot snow drifts between Holland and Sardina in southern Erie County. In northwestern Pennsylvania, also near Lake Erie, 12.4 inches of snow fell overnight at Erie, 4 of that in one hour, and the airport was closed. That contributed to a total 30-inch snow cover. A heavy snow warning in effect through Thursday was posted over northern Upper Michigan, and a winter storm watch in effect through Thursday was posted over western and northwest Lower Michigan. A high wind warning was posted for this afternoon and tonight over east central and southeast wyoming. A wind chill warning for tonight was posted over north central through northeast wyoming. Elsewhere, rain was scattered over the central Florida Peninsula, and from southern Mississippi into southeastern Louisiana. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 22 degrees below zero at Roseglen, N.D., Warroad, Minn., and Williston, N.D., to 84 at Homestead, Fla.
